Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story:
Tonight was supposed to be ours. My girlfriend and I had circled this evening on the calendar weeks ago, knowing it was the only one we’d have together before I left for a week-long training. She’d been dropping hints all day—her favorite movie queued up, dinner plans made, a bottle of wine chilling. I could feel her excitement, and I wanted to be there, fully present, to make her feel loved and important.

But as my shift was ending, I heard sobbing from down the hall. Mrs. Carter, one of my regular patients, had just been told her cancer had returned. She clung to my hand, her eyes searching mine for comfort, her voice trembling as she asked, “Will you stay with me a little longer?” I knew she had no family nearby, and the other nurses were swamped. My heart twisted—she needed me, too.

I stood in the hallway, phone buzzing with a sweet “Can’t wait to see you!” text, while Mrs. Carter’s cries echoed behind me. I felt torn in two, the weight of both their needs pressing down, unsure which door I should walk through.
